thesis.description: This thesis, written as part of a multi-discipline research project, examines the social factors which influence the course of pulmonary tuberculosis. The study is based on the examination of 40 patients, who were undergoing treatment at three sanatoria serving the Montreal area in 1953-54.
thesis.creator: Cameron, Dorothy.
Crowley, Anne
Good, Margot
MacEwan, Alison
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: The Impact of Social Factors in the Course of Pulmonary Tuberculosis.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The adaptation of the poultry industry to accommodate the needs of large scale production has resulted in the division of the industry into specialized units of meat and egg production. Egg production constitutes the major phase, from the aspect of both the percent of the total investment in the industry which is devoted to it and the number of flocks that is kept for egg production. It is to be expected then, that research study in the poultry field has until recently been devoted mainly to the problems associated with large-scale egg production. [...]
thesis.creator: Cadet, C.M.E.
thesis.subject: Poultry Husbandry.
thesis.title: The Effects of Antibiotics in the Laying Ration Upon Egg-Shell Quality.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The nitrification of ammonia and nitrite in soil is but one part of the overall nitrogen cycle. Essentially, nitrification may be defined as an oxidative-reductive mechanism whereby ammonium ions or nitrite ions are oxidized to nitrate by microorganisms.
thesis.creator: Brown, William Theophlus.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: the Metabolism of Alkylthioacids.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The term Classical Economics has been defined in various ways by different thinkers. Marx, who coined the term, used it to refer to Ricardo and the pre-Ricardians. He excluded the Socialist School (Bray, Hodgskin, Thompson, Gray, Sismondi, Proudhon) and the German Romantic School (Muller, Gentz, List). The one because of his kinship with them; the other because their methodology was tinged with ethical elements and was thus not scientifically objective.
thesis.creator: Brown, Irving.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: Classical Economic Methodology and its Critics.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This study concerns two research categories each consisting of twenty-five female employees. One category entitled the Absentee Group is comprised of employees who have been required to undergo medical examinations because of frequent absences from work; the other, entitled the Self-referred Group concerns employees who have reported to the medical department on their own initiative with minor physical complaints.
thesis.creator: Bernstein, Marianne
Wilson, Marilyn
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: Complaints of Employees from an Industrial Setting.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The material forming the basis of this work was obtained from reptiles, mainly lizards and snakes, from Egypt and nearby places. The collection was made time to time from January 1952 to May 1953 by members of the Department of Helminthology of the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 3, Cairo Egypt.
thesis.creator: Belle, Edward A.
thesis.subject: Parasitology.
thesis.title: Nematode Parasites of Egyptian Reptiles.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Kojic acid can be produced by a microbiological process from carbohydrates, and therefore it might serve as a very useful outlet for industrial and agricultural carbohydrate wastes. Since the acid has not yet found practical applications, the present research is directed toward making such application more probable by elucidating certain aspects of the chemistry of kojic acid where basic knowledge is at present lacking.
thesis.creator: Beelik, Andrew.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Some New Reactions and Derivatives of Kojic Acid.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Si le grand public ne connait guere Mérimée que par ses nouvelles, il faut pourtant remarquer que la place de la nouvelle dans l'oeuvre globale de Mérimée est en vérité assez restreinte. Mérimée a été un "historien avant tout" (1); il a été aussi un grand épistolier et il a consacré une large partie de sa vie a écrire de multiples articles sur l'architecture et des notes de voyage; il s'est intéressé au théâtre, au roman historique, et enfin il a écrit un certain nombre de préfaces et des portraits littéraires. [...]
thesis.creator: Beauchemin, Guy.
thesis.subject: French.
thesis.title: L'Art de la Nouvelle Chez Prosper Merimee.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Although we are mainly concerned with the psychological significance of muscle tension, it is important to bear in mind that this problem is but a part of a much broader one. The essential question before us is: What rationale underlies the study of physiological correlates of behavior?
thesis.creator: Bartoshuk, Alexander Karl.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: Electromyographic Gradients in Mirror Tracing.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The majority of investigations on the carotenoid pigments of bacteria have dealt with the identification of the types of carotenoids present in bacteria. Since the publication of Sullivan's paper in 1905 little work has been done to show which factors affect the synthesis of carotenoids in bacteria. Most of the investigations which have been conducted along this line have dealt with the effect of various carbon sources, inorganic ions, pH and temperature on pigmentation. [...]
thesis.creator: Baker, Harold Arthur.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology and Immunology.
thesis.title: the Carotenoid Pigments of Staphylococcus Pyogenes.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Metabolism of fatty acids in mammalian tissues has attracted active interest since the early days of biochemistry. Studies of biological oxidation of fatty acids originated with the work of Knoop, who fed 0-phenyl derivatives of several fatty acids to dogs and isolated the breakdown products of these substances. The animals excreted conjugated phenyl-acatic acid if an acid with an even number of carbons in the aliphatic chain was used and conjugated benzoic acid if the acid fed had an odd number of carbon atoms in the aliphatic chain. [...]
thesis.creator: Avigan, Joel.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Studies on the Metabolism of Fatty Acids in Animal Tissues.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The idea for this thesis originated with a graduate essay on the money market; the difficulty in locating any information on the topic presented something of a challenge. Research had elicited the information that published studies on Canadian money-market institutions are few in number; books on the short-term market are not only few in number, but non-existent, and their possibility seemed to be precluded by the generally-accepted statement that no such market exists in Canada. [...]
thesis.creator: Armstrong, Muriel G.B.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The Canadian Money Market.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The acceleration principle is a concept which has precipitated a series of controversies about its meaning, its importance, its mathematical form, its applicability, and the variables which it relates, to mention only a few. Like the female principal of the modern novel, the acceleration principle in the modern economic literature enjoys a questionable reputation. Despite the fact that its virtues and vices have been under more or less active consideration for the past thirty years, economists seem no closer to agreement than they were at the beginning on whether the acceleration principle should be granted a place among "respectable" economic theories.
thesis.creator: Armstrong, Donald. E.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The acceleration principle.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This investigation is one of a series which have been carried out in the Division of Industrial and Cellulose Chemistry at McGill University, in order to determine the chemical constituents of white spruce bark. Other investigations are still in progress. At present, bark is a major waste product in the pulp and paper industry. Not only does it possess little commercial value, but it also provides a difficult disposal problem. One object of these researches is to discover whether or not materials of potential value are present in the bark in sufficient amounts to justify their extraction on an industrial scale.
thesis.creator: Andrews, Douglas. H.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: A new glucoside from the crude phlobaphene fraction of white spruce bark.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The economic development of backward areas, an increasingly insistent problem before World War II, is now a major pre-occupation of the countries directly concerned and a primary purpose of the various post-war organizations for international cooperation. This emphasis on some immediate, significant improvement in the economic condition of so-called 'backward' countries is readily understandable considering the extreme mal-distribution of income and wealth in the world economy and the abject poverty in which whole populations find themselves.
thesis.creator: Adams, William. E.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The economics of development.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The development of any closed national economy from an agricultural, extractive economy to a highly industrialized one is dependent on the proportion of its national income (in real terms) which it is willing to devote to investment or capital accumulation. There are many definitions as to what constitutes investment but there is substantial agreement among economists as to the types of flows of goods and services covered by the term investment: “(1) expenditures on durable physical assets by entrepreneurs which (expenditures) consist of a) outlay on construction projects and the purchase of machinery and equipment; b) outlay on new house building including major improvements and alterations made by both homeowners and landlords; and c) outlay by governments on public buildings, engineering works, installations, resources development, and machinery and equipment” …
thesis.creator: Woodfine, William. J.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The effect of foreign investment – Canada, 1946-1951.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of this thesis is to trace the history of the Montreal Parks and Playgrounds from its beginnings in the year 1896 down to the present. This naturally will be a story of change, of shifting populations, of social conditions affecting the young people of this city and lastly, the attempts of the Montreal Parks and Playgrounds to meet recreational needs through the changing periods with which this thesis deals. From investigations made by the writer it was discovered that no histories of similar organizations have been written in Canada.
thesis.creator: Wilson, E. Laird.
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: The Montreal Parks and Playgrounds Associated Inc.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This study is concerned with the attitudes end reactions the public has towards psychiatry. These positive and negative feelings people have about psychiatry are often seen operating as persons are forced to live, work or play with one of their fellows who has been discharged from a hospital for the mentally ill. This project is an attempt to view some of the attitudes and reactions to psychiatry that emerge in the social intercourse that can exist between the person discharged from a psychiatric hospital and the public, as represented by employers and co-workers.
thesis.creator: Willis, Jackson. N.
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: An inquiry into the understanding of psychiatry shown in occupational settings.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The object of this investigation is to extend the theory of growth rates of Tarnishing Reactions to mechanisms which give rise to linear growth rates. This approach was stimulated by a Dr. E.J. Perry, who was investigating the kinetics of the formation of Triphenylmethyl and other Triarylmethyl free radicals in solution by the action of certain metals on the appropriate triarylmethyl halide. That is to say, he was trying to obtain information which would permit preparation of Triphenylmethyl free radicals in maximum concentration with minimum expenditure of time, preliminary to a projected investigation of certain reactions of the radicals themselves.
thesis.creator: Williams, Roscoe. C.
thesis.subject: Mathematics.
thesis.title: Linear growth laws in corrosive reactions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Samuel Butler (1835-1902), the author of Erewhom and The Way of All Flesh, has been dead for more than .fifty years. Although he left a comparatively small body of work, he has received nearly as much attention from the critics as his more prolific contemporaries. His fame, however, was not attained during his lifetime. Butler was never a leader with a following, the spokesman for a group. Typically his position was that of the solitary assailant of a theory otherwise unchallenged.
thesis.creator: Whimster, Eleanor. J.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The course of Butler’s literary fame.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This is a study of the role of the social worker in the treatment of twenty-two adolescent girls with emotional difficulties. They are not mentally defective girls or delinquent girls, but "normal" adolescents who have been referred to the Mental Hygiene Institute of Montreal because they displayed some symptom of disturbance. They have normal intelligence and normal physical capacities; they come from supposedly normal homes where one parent or both parents are present. They belong to the group which the child guidance centre is best able to help.
thesis.creator: Watson, Mary. T.
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: Casework aids to the adolescent girl.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: An attempt is made to interpret the ground state gamma radiation transitions due to thermal neutron capture in terms of the shell model of the nucleus. A new selection rule for magnetic multipole radiation is derived, which depends for its validity on the assumption that the orbital angular momentum of the individual particles is a good quantum number. It is found that the ground-state transitions are in general agreement with the shell models provided that the interaction between unpaired nucleons is taken into consideration.
thesis.creator: Vosko, Seymour. H.
thesis.subject: Mathematics.
thesis.title: Theoretical interpretation of radiation emitted in neutron capture reactions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The ultimate aim of the present research was to clarify the structure of cellulose xanthates, with particular reference to the positions of the xanthate groups within the glucose units. Some attempts have been made in recent years to solve this problem by substituting the unstable xanthate groups by the much more stable methyl groups, using diazomethane, and by studying the structure of the resulting methylcelluloses.
thesis.creator: Vincent, Donald. L.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Xanthate methyl esters of simple alcohols and of cellulose.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Although many fine editions have appeared, both ancient and modern, of Lucretius' De Rerum Natura", the one aspect of his style, "imagery", which forms the subject of this thesis, has not hitherto been adequately treated. Different editors have different views on Lucretius. Bailey holds that the most important single characteristic of Lucretius is his lofty and noble diction. Smith sees in the archaic tone of the poem the keynote of Lucretius' style. All, however, agree that the poem presents an uninterrupted sucession of varied and colourful pictures.
thesis.creator: Vallillee, Gerald. R.
thesis.subject: Classics.
thesis.title: Lucretian imagery.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The importance of good production control is increasing with the steady increase in productivity found in Canadian and American industry. (Normally, the United States manages to achieve a yearly gain of 2% in productivity.) In view of this it is insufficient to compare lost time, commonly called waiting time, of say ten years ago, with that of today and assume, because there has not been an increase, that the control system is operating satisfactorily. A much better indication of the effectiveness of the control system is a ratio of waiting time to productive time since the latter will likely have been decreasing steadily for the same unit of product.
thesis.creator: Tweed, William. J.
thesis.subject: Mechanical Engineering.
thesis.title: Mechanical aids for production control.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
